node.title: The Netherlands finds 61 Covid cases in air arrivals from South Africa, and is checking for the variant.
node.alt: Health workers transporting passengers from South Africa who tested positive for the coronavirus to a quarantine hotel in Schiphol, the Netherlands, on Saturday.
node.description: The passengers were in the air when the Netherlands announced travel restrictions on flights from southern Africa.
node.content: ["Sixty-one people from two flights from South Africa to the Netherlands have tested positive for the coronavirus, Dutch health officials said early Saturday. It was unclear as of late morning local time if the cases were linked to the newly discovered Omicron variant.", "The health officials tested 600 passengers who arrived on Friday morning at Amsterdam\u2019s Schiphol Airport. Those who tested negative were allowed to leave the airport and quarantine at home.", "When the Netherlands announced its travel restrictions on flights from southern Africa, the two KLM flights were already on their way to Schiphol. About half an hour before the first one landed, health officials were dispatched to the airport to conduct the tests there, said Harm Groustra, a spokesman for the GGD, the Dutch public health service.", "One of the passengers stuck on the tarmac was the New York Times reporter Stephanie Nolan, who had been in South Africa covering the country\u2019s response to the pandemic.", "\u201cSo I\u2019m in my 3d hour on a tarmac at Schiphol,\u201d she tweeted, after her flight from Johannesburg had landed. \u201cWhile my flight from Jo\u2019burg was somewhere over Chad, Europe went into variant panic; by the time we landed, we weren\u2019t allowed off the plane.\u201d", "Many passengers had ignored mask requirements, she said.", "Dutch health officials said in a statement that they were aware of frustration among passengers who thought that they were allowed to go home, but were instead \u201cconfronted with a situation like we\u2019ve never had before in the Netherlands.\u201d", "Hugo de Jonge, the country\u2019s health minister, tweeted that those with a positive test were being taken to a quarantine hotel near the airport. \u201cNow it\u2019s important to research whether this concerns the Omicron variant,\u201d he wrote.", "People who tested positive have to stay at the hotel for at least seven days if they have symptoms, or for five days if they do not, health officials said. Passengers who tested positive and live with people who were on the flight will be allowed to spend their quarantine at home.", "Cases have been rising quickly in the Netherlands, which yesterday announced stricter measures to try to curb the spread of the virus, including an evening lockdown that starts at 5 p.m. Last week, almost 154,000 people tested positive, a 39 percent increase from the week before.", "\u201cThe number of coronavirus infections has never been as high as in the past week,\u201d the government said on Friday, adding that the caseload was at risk of overwhelming hospitals in the country."]
